actor1: Military Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
notes: Movement of forces: Joint deployment of Ivoirian and Liberian military to the countries border began. The deployment is an effort to quash insurgent cross-border attacks from pro-Gbagbo Ivoirians and Liberian mercenaries hiding in Liberia. Military patrols will last until Jan. 3 and involve 1,600 Ivoirian troops as well as 414 Liberian soldiers. Military will patrol Ivoirian territory between the towns of Tai and Toulepleu, and along the Cavally River.

actor1: Military Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)

Hundreds of Alliance of Democratic Forces (AFD) supporters protested in Abidjan over a new Constitution project that was presented to the Parliament by president Ouattara three days prior. assoc_actor_1: Mutiny of Military Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
notes: Ivorian soldiers stage a mutiny in six towns in Ivory Coast (Bouake, Daloa, Daoukro, Korhogo, Odienne and Man) and take control of the towns by blocking road access, firing sporadic gunshots and reportedly forcing loyal forces to flee their posts. The mutineers are calling for better working conditions, including higher salaries, bonuses, and better career opportunities.

assoc_actor_1: Mutiny of Military Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
notes: Heavy gunfire rang out Monday in Abidjan and Bouake, Ivory Coast's two biggest cities, as a four-day mutiny by disgruntled soldiers demanding bonuses spread countrywide. Banks, offices and department stores closed their doors in the heart of the economic capital, Abidjan, as gunfire erupted in San Pedro, the second biggest port in the world's top cocoa-producing nation. The situation was also tense in Man in the west and Bondoukou and Daloa in the centre of the country, where sporadic shooting could be heard.

notes: Agreement: A four-day mutiny by ex-rebel soldiers in Ivory Coast has ended after they accepted a government offer, the mutineers say. The rebellion paralyzed cities and towns across the country. Renegade soldiers in Ivory Coast who have carried out a four-day nationwide mutiny said on Tuesday that they were ending their rebellion after accepting an amended offer from the government on bonus payments. The government had offered an immediate payment of 5 million CFA francs (7,500 Euros) and an extra 2 million to be paid at the end of next month, other spokesmen said.

assoc_actor_1: Mutiny of Military Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
notes: In Bouake, as well as into the key northern city of Korhogo, the former fighters blocked the main road south to the Ivorian economic capital, Abidjan, as well as the northern highway to neighbouring Burkina Faso.

actor2: Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
notes: Four people were killed and many hurt when police clashed with mutinous soldiers barricading the road into Bouake, in the spill over from a corrosive army mutiny over pay. The protesters said security forces opened fire to disperse them, but the government denied responsibility.

actor1: Police Forces of Ivory Coast (2011-) Gendarmerie
notes: Six people have been killed near the town of Arrah by gendarmes. The security officers were hunting down suspected armed robbers when they opened fire. Five funeral home workers and a passerby died. Four gendarmes and their commander were arrested.
People gathered to protest against soldiers' mutiny.
Opposition demonstrated against government's social policies.

actor2: Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)

actor1: Mutiny of Military Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
actor2: Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)

notes: Police station in Fresco was attacked by gunmen in military uniform. They held the policemen, took weapons and vehicles, and later robbed local treasure and banks.

actor2: Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
notes: Around 30 masked gunmen ambushed a police patrol in Adzope in La Me, took them to the police station and locked them in cells while they stole armaments. On their way out, they freed prisoners and looted local shops.

actor2: Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-) Prison Guards
notes: Five prisoners escaped from the Gagnoa prison threatening one of the guard with a gun. Five guards were later arrested for complicity.

actor2: Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-) Prison Guards
notes: 20 detained escaped from the Abidjan Court after harassing the guards. Seven guards were later arrested.
Youth with machetes allegedly terrorised people and pursued passers-by for unclear reasons. Wounded are reported.

actor2: Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
notes: Students went on strike to protest the lack of student housing. There were clashes between police and students leading to several protesters sustaining wounds.

People went to the street to protest against bad route conditions and general insecurity.

actor2: Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
notes: Students protesting high registration fees and police forces clashed. 3 students were wounded.
A situation between two youngsters triggered some clashes between autochthonous and non-native communities. People of both parts were wounded, and some houses were burnt down.

In the last two weeks, two people died and several were wounded when a land conflict sprung up in the Western part of the country.

Inter-community clashes for the exploitation of Goin-Debe forest during several weeks: 10 dead, 28 wounded, 2 rape cases and 4 campements burned.

notes: Thousands of Bethleem schools students set up a march to protest the lack of teaching, as schools were destroyed Thursday by a conflict between the school founder and locals. Students were armed with clubs. They interrupted teaching in several school and blocked northern axis. They were eventually dispersed by police.

Further deterioration of relations between communities in the Cavally region and more particularly in Guiglo: on Thursday, November 2, 2017, in the village of Glopahoudy, the young Sronhon Evariste, president of the young people of Beoua and Gouehi Sede Marius went to the field and fall into a trap laid by strangers.

actor1: Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
notes: Tense situation in Massakro between the military and the population. A 25-year-old man was killed by a soldier: the man was transporting cocoa to neighbouring Ghana despite the ban. Questioned by the soldier, disputes ensued when the villagers came out to lynch the element. To defend himself, the latter made two warning shots in an attempt to dissuade them.

Occupiers of a protected area ransacked Ivorian offices of Water and Forests and conservation agencies in Katiola to protest against their expulsion from the Haut Bandama reserve. 'People attacked the offices of Water and Forests' of SODEFOR (Forest Development Corporation) and OIPR (Ivorian Office of Parks and Reserves).

Clashes of a rare violence between the students of the high school governor Abdoulaye Fadiga (Gaf) and those of the private secondary school, Kone Mamadou (Ckm), made several wounded and the two institutions ransacked

notes: Students threw stones at police and dislodged teachers and other students of high schools and colleges of Korhogo with stones and clubs. The protesters denounced in particular the lack of tables and benches in the high school Dominique Ouattara of the city.

Suspected Yacouba killed a Lobi in Mahapieu. The Lobi killed a Yacouba civilian in retaliation, leading to wider clashes between the two groups, leaving several people injured. All the incidents occurred in the space of one day.

Young Ivorians protested at the Lagnonkaha mining company in Guiembe, Korhogo, against the exploitation of a manganese mine by an Indian company, demanding their recruitment within the company. They set up barricades on the main road that leads to the exploitation site.

Students in Touba, Korhogo, Ferkessedougou and Abengourou threw stones on the roof of classrooms and loud darts of firecrackers to call for an earlier end of classrooms before the holidays. Police intervened to disperse them with tear gas or batons. In Korhogo, the students threw stones at professors and students, leaving some of them injured.

actor2: Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
notes: Urban transport experienced a disturbance in the municipality of Treichville as two groups of young trade unionists protested at Bassam Station. Security forces arrested several people as they intervened to avoid a clash.

actor2: Military Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
notes: An exchange of fire killed two people in the night from Thursday to Friday at a checkpoint in Bangolo. Unidentified gunmen broke into the checkpoint usually held by soldiers. In the absence of the security forces, the attackers opened fire on two young villagers who are used to assist security guards in the surveillance missions.

On August 27, an armed group armed with Kalashnikovs and dressed in military fatigues looted a school and sequestered the guardian of the establishment, hitting him with rifle butts, tying him up and gagging him with pieces of torn curtains.
On August 28, youth from Katiola set the village of Atienkaha on fire, Humbol, protesting the disappearance of a young driver.
On August 30, a group of women from several neighbourhoods in the city of Katiola, Hambol, marched to protest the disappearance of a young driver.

assoc_actor_1: FESCI: Student Federation of Ivory Coast; Students (Ivory Coast)

On September 20th, two youth groups clashed in the village of Odienne, killing one person and injuring two others.
On Sept 26 Adiake Municipal High School students demonstrated across the city contesting the extra fees they have to pay after registration.

actor1: Military Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
assoc_actor_1: Military Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-) Gendarmerie; Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)

On Oct 2, workers from the Rubber Company of Grand-Bereby (SOGB), who have been on strike for more than two weeks to demand an increase in wages, demonstrated in front of the entrance of the offices of the company in San Pedro.

actor1: RHDP: Rally of Houphouetistes for Democracy and Peace

On Oct 13, electoral voting boxes were smashed up and set on fire in Bonoua, east of the commercial capital Abidjan.

On October 13, after the release of the provisional results of the national elections, the buildings of the Independent Electoral Commission (CEI) in Sangouine (26 km from Man), were ransacked. Nobody was injured.

actor2: Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
notes: In the night of Oct 15, clashes between police and rioters left some people injured in Grand-Bassam, near Ivory Coast's main city Abidjan. Riot police used teargas to disperse the crowd of demonstrators asking for the release of results for the elections in the country.

assoc_actor_2: PDCI: Democratic Party of Ivory Coast
notes: On October 16, the vehicle of the father of PDCI candidate Vremen Serge Yvon, was destroyed by rioters in Tanda. Nobody was injured and the police intervened soon after to stop these acts of vandalism.

actor2: Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)

actor2: Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)

assoc_actor_1: PDCI: Democratic Party of Ivory Coast

On October 19, a teacher was killed by an unknown armed group in Bonon.
On Oct 22, students marched in the city of Madinani to protest teacher shortages in their school.
On Oct 22, the teaching staff serving in the three public secondary schools in the city of Seguela has launched a march in the streets of the city to protest the insecurity.

actor2: Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
notes: On Oct 24, teachers and students stormed Tengrela police station after a dispute between a teacher and the police in which a woman was assaulted.
On Nov 2, an unknown gunman opened fire on participants at a funeral vigil in Gloplou village in Bangolo Department, resulting in four wounded by bullets.

actor1: Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
notes: On November 8, in Korhogo, human rights activist Carton Noir was arrested by police forces while he was allegedly filming policemen extorting money from drivers. He was taken to an unknown destination, his where about remain unknown.

On Nov 10, people with disabilities organized a demonstration in front of the premises of the Gagnoa community rehabilitation centre for the handicapped (RACH) to demand the resignation of the board of directors of the structure.

On Nov 21, students clashed in the streets with drivers in Zouan-hounien, in western Cote d'Ivoire, after the death of a 12-year-old, at the Zouan-Hounien Municipal High School who was reportedly beaten by a driver.
On 23 Nov 2018, unidentified armed assailants ambushed three cars and about a dozen motorcycles on the road between Bettie, Yakasse and Attobrou. The passengers were stripped of their possessions.

On or around 26 Nov 2018, several young people attacked each other with machetes over the control of a smoking room in Kpimbly neighbourhood, Yopougon, Abidjan. The clash resulted in the death of one of the youth involved.

On 26 Nov 2018, a group of youth aggressors involving drivers and apprentice drivers also known as 'gnambro' armed with knives and machetes ransacked a high school in Duekoue. The attack was allegedly a retaliation for a teachers' strike the week before, during which students damaged vehicles. One student was allegedly killed and about a dozen others wounded, including four with bullet wounds.
On 27 Nov 2018, a man was stabbed to death by unidentified assailants in Angre, Abidjan. The attack was allegedly carried out as a settlement for a previous conflict.
On 27 November, a student went missing in Dabakala. He was found dead a week later, on 7 December.
On 28 Nov 2018, trainee teachers staged a sit-in in front of Odienne's treasury offices, protesting against the non-payment of their scholarships during the entire year.

actor1: Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-) Prison Guards

On 10 Dec 2018, students from Dabakala high school demonstrated against the killing of one of their peers in Dabakala. The demonstrators threw stones and blocked the main road. The student, who had been missing since 27 Nov, was found dead on 7 Dec.

actor2: Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)

actor2: Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)

actor2: Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)

actor2: Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
